Claude Shannon was an American mathematician, electrical engineer, and cryptographer known as "the father of information theory". Born in 1916, Shannon graduated from the University of Michigan in 1936 with two bachelor's degrees in electrical engineering and mathematics. He then began his graduate studies in electrical engineering at MIT, where his master's degree thesis won him the Alfred Noble American Institute of American Engineers Award in 1939. Howard Gardner also praised his thesis, saying that it was "possibly the most important, and also the most famous, master's thesis of the century". 
 

During WWII Shannon undertook important studies into what would become the field of Information Theory, fire-control systems, and cryptography (where he worked with Alan Turing for some months in Washington). A notable achievement of his was proving that the cryptographic one-time pad is unbreakable, and that any unbreakable system must have certain characteristics (such as a truly random key, etc). 
 

He also founded the field of Information Theory, where he made massive contributions to natural language processing and digital signal transmission. 
 

His interests were not limited to his work however. Among other things he invented the 'Theseus' (as seen in the above image), an electromechanical mouse that could navigate different mazes and learn from it's experience. It is considered to be the first artificial learning device of it's kind. 
 

He developed Alzheimer's disease as he got older, and spent his last years in a nursing home Massachusetts. He died in 2001, leaving behind a rich legacy.
Neil Sloane has stated that "He's one of the great men of the century. Without him, none of the things we know today would exist. The whole digital revolution started with him".

Edsger Dijkstra was a Dutch computer scientist. He was born in Rotterdam in 1930, and originally studied theoretical physics at Leiden University but soon switched to computer science. He held positions at the Mathematisch Centrum, Eindhoven University of Technology, Burroughs Corporation, and the University of Texas at Austin. 
 

Among his contributions to computer science are a shortest path algorithm (also know as Dijkstra's algorithm), the Shunting yard algorithm, the THE multiprogramming system, the Banker's algorithm, and the semaphore construct for coordinating multiple processors and programs. Another concept due to Dijkstra in the field of distributed computing is that of self-stabilization â€“ an alternative way to ensure the reliability of the system. Dijkstra's algorithm is used in SPF, Shortest Path First, which is used in the routing protocols OSPF and IS-IS. 
 

On a more humorous note, Dijkstra was also responsible for the introduction of the term 'Considered Harmful' into the field of computer science. He started it by writing a paper critizizing excessive use of the GOTO statement, and it was published by the ACM as "Go To Statement Considered Harmful"; a response to this paper was entitled "'Go To Statement Considered Harmful' Considered Harmful", and the response to that paper was entitled ""'Go To Statement Considered Harmful' Considered Harmful" Considered Harmful?"
He died in Nuenen on 6 August 2002 after a long struggle with cancer. The following year, the ACM PODC Influential Paper Award in distributed computing was renamed the Dijkstra Prize in his honor.
